The "Home Health Equity Act of 1999" eliminates the automatic 15 percent reduction in home health payments and includes a waiver of per beneficiary limits for outliers in home health services. The Secretary shall use provider data for determinations and applications for additional payments must be made no earlier than the end of the cost reporting period. The total additional payments to home health agencies shall be between 3 to 4 percent of the amounts that would have been paid without the Act. The amendment takes effect upon enactment and applies to applications for payment of reasonable costs for outliers submitted by home health agencies. The Home Health Equity Act of 1999 allows home health agencies to apply for additional payments for outliers submitted for cost reporting periods after September 30, 1999. SEC. 4. RECOUPMENT OF OVERPAYMENTS. The text chunk discusses a 36-month repayment period for overpayments made by the Secretary of Health and Human Services to home health agencies for services provided. Home health agencies can elect to repay the overpayment amount over 36 months, except if any final adverse action has been taken against the agency. No interest accrues on overpayment amounts for 36 months if an agency elects to do so. The election cannot be made for cost reporting periods after the implementation of the prospective payment system for home health services. The provisions are effective as if included in the Balanced Budget Act of 1997. SEC. 5. INCREASE IN PAYMENT AMOUNT TO AGENCIES WITH LIMITS UNDER THE NATIONAL AVERAGE. The Social Security Act is amended to increase payment amounts to agencies with limits under the national average for cost reporting periods beginning in fiscal years 1999, 2000, and after 2001. The provisions of this amendment shall take effect as if included in the enactment of the Tax and Trade Relief Extension Act of 1998. The Social Security Act is amended to increase payment amounts to agencies with limits under the national average for cost reporting periods beginning in fiscal years 1999, 2000, and after 2001, with provisions taking effect as if included in the enactment of the Tax and Trade Relief Extension Act of 1998. SEC. 6. INCREASE IN PER VISIT LIMIT. Amends the Social Security Act to increase payment amounts for agencies with limits below the national average for cost reporting periods starting in fiscal years 1999, 2000, and after 2001. SEC. 7. ELIMINATION OF TIMEKEEPING REQUIREMENTS UNDER THE PROSPECTIVE PAYMENT SYSTEM FOR HOME HEALTH AGENCIES. SEC. 8 amends Section 1895(c) of the Social Security Act regarding home health agencies' payment provisions and specifies the effective date of the amendments. SEC. 8 amends payment provisions for home health agencies until the prospective payment system is implemented. SEC. 9 revises the surety bond requirement for home health agencies. SEC. 9 amends the surety bond requirement for home health agencies to protect against overpayments from fraudulent claims. The amendment will take effect upon enactment of the Act. Section 1839(g) of the Social Security Act is amended to adjust the per visit limit percentages under certain clauses of section 1861(v)(1)(L).
